topics.title: Cold open: vision selling, pricing, differentiation
topics.summary: Jen and Lenny open with rapid-fire principles: sell the opportunity (gap) not the problem, avoid discounting/nickel-and-diming, differentiate so you’re not compared, and treat enterprise sales as relationship-driven and creative.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Jen Abel, frames this as part two (from ~$1M to ~$10M ARR), and sets expectations for a tactical enterprise-sales deep dive.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for WorkOS and Lovable, followed by Lenny welcoming Jen back to the show.

topics.title: Why the mid-market “doesn’t exist”
topics.summary: Jen argues “mid-market” is an ambiguous label; selling motions differ drastically between SMB and enterprise, so teams should explicitly choose which game they’re playing (upper SMB vs lower enterprise).

topics.title: Go after tier-one logos earlier
topics.summary: Contrary to common advice, Jen recommends targeting top-tier market leaders early because they must stay #1, will take swings for “alpha,” can shape roadmap, and provide powerful proof and pull-through.

topics.title: How to approach enterprise: sell the gap
topics.summary: Jen explains tactical outreach and messaging: involve the founder, vision-cast, and sell an opportunity/“alpha” rather than interrogating for problems; examples include positioning tools like Cursor as talent/advantage multipliers.

topics.title: Pricing confidence: avoid small deals and discounting
topics.summary: Jen argues founders overvalue many small deals and over-discount; enterprise buyers who nickel-and-dime aren’t bought in, and $100K+ deals force executive sponsorship, better fit, and healthier expansion math.

topics.title: Don’t anchor enterprise with SMB pricing
topics.summary: Jen warns that letting an enterprise buy via SMB/PLG pricing (e.g., a few seats on a credit card) creates a damaging reference point that makes later expansion to $75K–$150K+ hard to defend—especially with contract analysis tools.

topics.title: Design partners: choose wisely and set framing
topics.summary: Jen describes how to use design partners for learning (often tech-forward enterprises), why they’re hardest to convert, and how to set expectations on product maturity, pricing trajectory, and perpetual concessions without losing the enterprise path.

topics.title: Choosing SMB vs enterprise and AI-era constraints
topics.summary: They discuss how founders should pick the GTM motion they understand best, how AI may shift “enterprise” definitions (headcount), and why low-risk entry points matter when enterprise data/integrations raise risk.

topics.title: Enterprise sales as art: deal crafting and services
topics.summary: Jen frames 1–10M enterprise selling as creative deal crafting: add high-value/low-cost concessions, avoid becoming a comparison, and use services/forward-deployed work to get in the door and later transition customers to product.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Coda, describing its all-in-one workspace and a startup team-plan offer.

topics.title: Forward-deployed, channels skepticism, and recap
topics.summary: Jen reinforces the “butt-in-seat” model (Palantir/McKinsey style), critiques channel-partner fantasies (e.g., Accenture), and Lenny summarizes key takeaways: target tier-one logos, move ACV toward ~$75K–$150K+, and use services strategically.
